title.children: ACT government says it won't investigate leaking of Bruce Lehrmann report — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people. The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June. The new charges include nine offences each of alleged dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm. There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hunter Valley wedding bus crash driver faces 43 additional charges

featuredLink.title: Hunter Valley bus crash driver to face 43 additional charges

children.content: An additional 43 charges have been laid against a bus driver who was at the wheel of a coach that
crashed in the Hunter Valley, killing 10 people.
The bus carrying wedding guests rolled on a roundabout near the Hunter Expressway at Greta in June.
The new charges include nine offences each of alleged dangerous and negligent driving occasioning grievous bodily harm.
There are also 25 new charges of causing bodily harm by misconduct.
You can read more on this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACT government says it will not investigate the leaking of the board of inquiry report into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann. Copies of the report have been leaked to the media. The ABC has decided not to publish excerpts of the report for now due to legal reasons. The ACT government has received the report from Walter Sofronoff and said it will stick to its original timetable and release it later in the month after considering its findings. A statement from the Chief Minister Andrew Barr says the leak of the report did not come from the ACT cabinet. The ACT opposition says it's essential the government release the full report.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ACT government says it won't investigate leaking of Lehrmann report

props.alt: A man with a beard and glasses walking outside and wearing a suit.

children.content: (AAP: Mick Tsikas)
The ACT government says it will not investigate the leaking of the board of inquiry report into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann.
Copies of the report have been leaked to the media.
The ABC has decided not to publish excerpts of the report for now due to legal reasons.
The ACT government has received the report from Walter Sofronoff and said it will stick to its original timetable and release it later in the month after considering its findings.
A statement from the Chief Minister Andrew Barr says the leak of the report did not come from the ACT cabinet.
The ACT opposition says it's essential the government release the full report.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games. In an unprecedented move yesterday, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle. But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear — including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister. Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings. "This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry. "If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation

props.alt: A close up of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, speaking outside while wearing a suit and glasses

children.content: (AAP: James Ross)
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games.
In an unprecedented move yesterday
, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle.
But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear
— including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister.
Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings.
"This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry.
"If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague Michael Janda has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit. At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but its now about 65.31 US cents. It also lost more than a per cent last night. A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise). Across the ditch in New Zealand their dollar is also lower against the greenback.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dollar down

children.content: Those underwhelming retail figures my colleague
Michael Janda
has been posting about have seen the Australian dollar take another hit.
At midday it was about 65.45 US cents, but its now about 65.31 US cents.
It also lost more than a per cent last night.
A lot of it has to do with what the market thinks about the RBA's interest rate decision (and future moves or otherwise).
Across the ditch in New Zealand their dollar is also lower against the greenback.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Downer EDI announced it expects to report a statutory net loss after tax of about $386 million for the 2023 financial year. The company will write off almost $550 million when it reports its full year results to the market next week. The impairment comes from increased debt costs and "tightening market conditions" for its cleaning and maintenance business Spotless, which caters to the defence sector. Downer EDI lowered its forecasts after lawsuits were filed alleging breaches of disclosures regarding a maintenance contract and the Sydney-based company revealed accounting irregularities in December. "Downer is undergoing a period of significant and necessary organisational change. Against this backdrop, we have delivered underlying earnings in line with what was previously communicated," CEO Peter Tompkins said in a statement. Downer EDI posted their biggest single day loss in six months, falling nearly 6 per cent, but have recovered some of that fall in mid afternoon trade to sit a bit over two per cent below yesterday's closing figure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Downer EDI a downer on the market today

children.content: Downer EDI
announced it expects to report a
statutory net loss
after tax of about
$386 million
for the 2023 financial year.
The company will
write off almost $550 million
when it reports its full year results to the market next week.
The impairment comes from increased debt costs and "tightening market conditions" for its cleaning and maintenance business Spotless, which caters to the defence sector.

Downer EDI lowered its forecasts after lawsuits were filed alleging breaches of disclosures regarding a maintenance contract and the Sydney-based company revealed accounting irregularities in December.

"Downer is undergoing a period of significant and necessary organisational change. Against this backdrop, we have delivered underlying earnings in line with what was previously communicated," CEO Peter Tompkins said in a statement.
Downer EDI posted their
biggest single day loss in six months
, falling nearly 6 per cent, but have recovered some of that fall in mid afternoon trade to sit a bit over two per cent below yesterday's closing figure.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a bit of movement on the ASX today among some companies in the battery metals space. Australian Strategic Materials (ASM), which owns deposits in New South Wales (though is yet to mine anything and sources its rare earths ore from other miners in Asia), has signed a deal with USA Rare Earth. ASM owns a rare earths processing plant in South Korea — that arm of the business has signed a five-year deal with the US company to supply neodymium iron boron alloy from 2024. Neodymium is used to make permanent magnets for things like medical imaging machines, engines and communications technology. It's shares are up more than 5 per cent. Liontown Resources, which mines lithium (another critical component in batteries) in the Goldfields region of WA, announced today it will export lithium direct shipping ore (DSO) (the least refined product) before it exports its first concentrate (ore that's been partly refined) as way to raise some cash. Liontown has so far stockpiled 70,000 tonnes of DSO and expects to sell up to 300,000 tonnes, likely starting by the end of this calendar year. Liontown's m anaging director and CEO, Tony Ottaviano, said: "Progressing with the production of DSO not only provides early revenue potential, but also enables us to de-risk the project by field testing our ore sorting and logistics solutions on a smaller scale ahead of first concentrate production mid-2024." Liontown shares are up 0.2 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Battery Metals in demand
